captions.text: the German mathematician David Hilbert
devised a famous thought experiment
to show us just how hard it is

to wrap our minds
around the concept of infinity.

Imagine a hotel with an infinite
number of rooms
and a very hardworking night manager.

One night, the Infinite Hotel
is completely full,

totally booked up
with an infinite number of guests.

A man walks into the hotel
and asks for a room.
Rather than turn him down,

the night manager decides
to make room for him.
How?
Easy, he asks the guest in room number 1
to move to room 2,
the guest in room 2 to move to room 3,
and so on.
Every guest moves from room number "n"
to room number "n+1".

Since there are an infinite
number of rooms,

there is a new room
for each existing guest.

This leaves room 1 open
for the new customer.
The process can be repeated
for any finite number of new guests.

If, say, a tour bus unloads
40 new people looking for rooms,
then every existing guest just moves
from room number "n"
to room number "n+40",
thus, opening up the first 40 rooms.
But now an infinitely large bus

with a countedly infinite
number of passengers
pulls up to rent rooms.
Countedly infinite is the key.

Now, the infinite bus
of infinite passengers
perplexes the night manager at first,
but he realizes there's a way
to place each new person.

He asks the guest in room 1
to move to room 2.
He then asks the guest in room 2
to move to room 4,
the guest in room 3 to move to room 6,
and so on.

Each current guest moves
from room number "n"
to room number "2n" --

filling up only the infinite
even-numbered rooms.
By doing this, he has now emptied

all of the infinitely many
odd-numbered rooms,

which are then taken by the people
filing off the infinite bus.

Everyone's happy and the hotel's business
is booming more than ever.

Well, actually, it is booming
exactly the same amount as ever,

banking an infinite number
of dollars a night.
Word spreads about this incredible hotel.
People pour in from far and wide.
One night, the unthinkable happens.
The night manager looks outside

and sees an infinite line
of infinitely large buses,

each with a countedly infinite
number of passengers.
What can he do?

If he cannot find rooms for them,
the hotel will lose out
on an infinite amount of money,
and he will surely lose his job.

Luckily, he remembers
that around the year 300 B.C.E.,

Euclid proved that there
is an infinite quantity
of prime numbers.

So, to accomplish this
seemingly impossible task

of finding infinite beds
for infinite buses
of infinite weary travelers,

the night manager assigns
every current guest
to the first prime number, 2,

raised to the power
of their current room number.
So, the current occupant of room number 7
goes to room number 2^7,
which is room 128.

The night manager then takes the people
on the first of the infinite buses
and assigns them to the room number
of the next prime, 3,

raised to the power of their seat
number on the bus.

So, the person in seat
number 7 on the first bus
goes to room number 3^7
or room number 2,187.
This continues for all of the first bus.
The passengers on the second bus
are assigned powers of the next prime, 5.
The following bus, powers of 7.
Each bus follows:
powers of 11, powers of 13,
powers of 17, etc.
Since each of these numbers
only has 1 and the natural number powers
of their prime number base as factors,
there are no overlapping room numbers.

All the buses' passengers
fan out into rooms
using unique room-assignment schemes
based on unique prime numbers.

In this way, the night
manager can accommodate
every passenger on every bus.

Although, there will be
many rooms that go unfilled,
like room 6,

since 6 is not a power
of any prime number.

Luckily, his bosses
weren't very good in math,
so his job is safe.

The night manager's strategies
are only possible

because while the Infinite Hotel
is certainly a logistical nightmare,

it only deals with the lowest
level of infinity,

mainly, the countable infinity
of the natural numbers,
1, 2, 3, 4, and so on.

Georg Cantor called this level
of infinity aleph-zero.

We use natural numbers
for the room numbers
as well as the seat numbers on the buses.

If we were dealing
with higher orders of infinity,
such as that of the real numbers,

these structured strategies
would no longer be possible

as we have no way
to systematically include every number.
The Real Number Infinite Hotel
has negative number rooms in the basement,
fractional rooms,
so the guy in room 1/2 always suspects
he has less room than the guy in room 1.
Square root rooms, like room radical 2,
and room pi,
where the guests expect free dessert.

What self-respecting night manager
would ever want to work there
even for an infinite salary?
But over at Hilbert's Infinite Hotel,
where there's never any vacancy
and always room for more,
the scenarios faced by the ever-diligent
and maybe too hospitable night manager
serve to remind us of just how hard it is
for our relatively finite minds
to grasp a concept as large as infinity.
Maybe you can help tackle these problems
after a good night's sleep.
But honestly, we might need you
to change rooms at 2 a.m.

title: The Infinite Hotel Paradox - Jeff Dekofsky

comments.author: magic tech reviews (john)

comments.text:
If I were the night manager, I would use another way to assign rooms, 
easier to calculate and without lefting any rooms (sorry for my bad 
English).

I identify every passenger with two natural numbers, "i", which is 1 for 
the hotel 2 for the first bus 3 for the second bus and so on, "j" for the 
room where he come from.

So, the person who occupy the 10th ton of hotel, I call him (1;10).

The person who sit in the 11th seat of the third bus, I call him (4;11).

Now, it's time to assign room's.

The person ( i ; j ) will sleep in rooms number 

(i+j)*(i+j-1)/2 - (j-1)

Everybody have his own room, but there's no empty room.



﻿

However, it gets tricky when 0 becomes part of infinity, e.g. INF / 0 = INF 
| 0 | both | none.﻿

comments.author: Gunbardo

comments.text:
The metaphor of the infinite hotel was concocted by David Hilbert, one of 
the greatest mathematicians of his time, as a way to allow 
non-mathematicians to better understand how infinite sets have properties 
that are contrary to our intuition.  It still stands today, 100 years 
later, as one of the best metaphors for the mathematical concept.

comments.author: iamihop

comments.text:
+María Ley But do you really understand the "mathematical meaning of 
infinity", if so how? What about when we start talking about computability, 
decidability (or semi-decidability) of languages? Undecidability of halting 
problem for example really points to theoretical limitations of our 
understanding of infinity... (and rant can go on with equality of 
computable real numbers, Axiom of Choice & Banach-Tarsky paradox, etc)
One can not go past a non-terminating process (for example moving guests in 
the hotel) and then expect the results "at the end" to be consistent.
comments.author: agemo2007ed

comments.text:
+iamihop you certainly do not understand the mathematical meaning of 
infinity x) yet you seem to speak really confident about your interpretation
comments.author: María Ley

comments.text:
+Nameguy Thought experiments allow us to imagine the results if certain 
premises are accepted, even if those premises are outside of our ability to 
actually test. However, they are meaningless unless they are *internally 
consistent*. A full infinite hotel is self-contradictory and not internally 
consistent. Therefore, any hypothetical conclusions stemming from that 
premise aren't valid.
comments.author: iamihop

comments.text: +iamihop I believe you miss the purpose of thought experiments, then.
comments.author: Nameguy

comments.text:

comments.text:
For the infinite buses of infinite people, you list them the same way as 
the rational numbers (fractions) on a grid and trace diagonal lines through 
the grid.
Then you move existing people to double their room number and put the 
listed newcomers in the odd number rooms. No empty rooms and shorter walks 
for the customers than the prime number method.﻿
comments.author: Tim Lewis

comments.text:
For the infinite amount of people in infinite buses, instead of that prime 
numbers and powers thing (which would require longer walks for your 
customers), I would have converted it into a grid where you have bus number 
on 1 axis and person number on the other axis, then list diagonally through 
the grid (e.g. with (Person,Bus) you'd go
(1,1); (1,2),(2,1); (1,3),(2,2),(3,1); (1,4),(2,3),(3,2),(4,1) etc. Then 
get everyone already in the hotel to move to double their room number as 
before, leaving no empty rooms in the sequence.
Using this system Person 1 of Bus 1 would be assigned to room 1, Person 1 
of Bus 2 would be assigned to room 3 (move along the list).﻿

comments.author: DeePal072

comments.text:
The problem people often seem to have with infinity is that infinity is 
uncountable even if made up of countable objects. Countable infinity doesnt 
mean you can count to it but that the object of said infinity can be listed 
(they are separated entities). There are 3 infinities I know of: countable 
infinity (made up of integers, the sum of which is infinite) dense infinity 
(fractions and geometric series that are infinite within a finite range) 
and "real" infinity (that includes numbers that round up infinitely like 
pi, phi and squareroot of 2). There might be other infinities out there I 
am not in the know of cause I am not a mathematician. The problems here 
represented can be expressed as
C.Inf.+n where n is an integer equals C.inf.
C.inf+c.inf=c.inf. and by extention Xc.inf.+c.inf where x is an integer 
equals c.inf.﻿

as an infinite amount ("infinity") of guests in the infinite amount of 
rooms (which equals "infinity"), and there is an infinite amount of guests

of guests in the rooms + the amount of guests in the lobby.﻿

comments.text:
+Gabriel Colley But if +columbus8myhw's elevator follows the rule that the 
time taken to get from the current floor to the next being 1/x^2 (With x 
being the current floor), he's still correct, no matter how high the floor 
is, even travelling from 1 to infinity, as the travel time decreases per 
floor. The time taken to reach your destination just approaches 2 seconds 
as you approach infinity.
For individual floor travel, the travel time approaches the asymptote of 0 
as the starting floor approaches infinity, where the travel time from floor 
infinity to something higher would be 0 seconds.
If this doesn't make sense, I have no idea how to explain this properly.

Basically - Time taken to travel up 1 floor = 1/x^2, where x = current 
floor. Then to calculate multiple floors, add the times taken to travel 
between floors. Travelling from floor 1 to infinity takes 2 seconds.
comments.author: Sir Edward (Crossbow711)

infinite = Xbus * Xguests * infinite   this equation is always true for any 
X>0 
and by the way nothing in this universe is infinite, so this video is even 
more stupid to watch. 

“Two things are infinite: the universe and human stupidity; and I'm not 
sure about the universe.” Albert Einstein

comments.text:
+TowerJimmy infinity is an abstract concept of maths not a value. You can't 
just conduct normal mathematical operations because it doesn't make sense 
with infinity. infinity + infinity is still equal to infinity and thus 
solves nothing. So you have to use finite numbers to solve problems with 
infinity and this is where the maths come into the equation. Besides, it is 
meant as a thought experiment and hence is NOT SUPPOSED TO BE REAL

comments.author: MoJo

comments.text:
This DOES NOT WORK because:

Guests DO NOT move from room number n to room number n+1, the shuffling 
must start at infinity, where a new room is opened up designated as room 
number "infinity plus one", and rooms get shuffled into the adjacent 
vacancies that get opened up along the way, BACKWARDS to room number 1.

In other words, the shuffling does not start at room number 1, it starts at 
the end of capacity, then shuffling the previous rooms all the way back to 
room number 2, and then the guests from room number 1 can vacate it for the 
hotel's new guests.

You ask, WHY DO ROOMS HAVE TO BE SHUFFLED FROM THE END, BACKWARDS,  RATHER 
THAN FROM ROOM ONE, FORWARD (as this video states)?

Let's try it, both ways, but with a FINITE SIZE hotel with 10 rooms:

In the BACKWARDS shuffle (that I am claiming MUST be used), it's really 
easy. First, the guests in room number 10 are moved forward into the corn 
field, thus vacating it. Next, the guests in room number 9 are moved 
forward directly into room number 10, no waiting for anything else to 
happen. The next STEP in the SEQUENCE is for the guests in room number 8 to 
move into room number 9, etc, ONE STEP AT A TIME, all the way BACKWARDS to 
room number 1, whose guests get moved into room number 2, leaving room 
number 1 vacant for the new guests who check in. Simple, right? ONE bellhop 
can get it all done because it all happens in 11 steps, one room at a time.

In the FORWARD shuffle (used in all of the examples in this video), yes, 
the guests in room number 1 do move into room number 2, and so the guests 
in room number 2 have to move, and so they move into room number 3, leaving 
room number 2 vacant, allowing the (former room 1) guests who were WAITING 
OUT IN THE PARKING LOT for room number 2 to be vacated, to move. As this 
chain of events progresses FORWARD, the guests in room number 9 will "push" 
the guests in room number 10 into the cornfield, and everyone can finally 
get some sleep, ESPECIALLY THE BELLHOP, who had to PERFORM 3 times the 
number of steps, as compared with the backwards shuffle method.

HEY, no big problem, they just had to give him a bigger tip, right?

OK, that was no big problem for ONE roomful of guest checking in, but what 
if 2 want to check in at the same time (leading up to the example of a 
busloads of guests arriving)... hmmm, let's see... with 2 set of guests, we 
now need to hold the guests of BOTH rooms 2 AND 3 out in the parking lot, 
RIGHT? And now, the poor bellhop needs to make 5 times the number of total 
steps to accomplish the task.

With 3 new guests, this now means holding 3 room-fulls of guests out in the 
parking lot, and it now takes 7 times as many steps to accomplish vs the 
simple BACKWARDS shuffle method.

Etc... And not only that, the total count of bellhop steps DOUBLES for 
every new room added to the capacity of "finite hotel" using forward 
shuffling, but only increases by 2 steps for each room number using 
backwards shuffling.

As the numbers of new guests arriving increases, the amount of QUEUING in 
the parking lot becomes proportional to the count of new guests, and the 
count of steps it takes for the bellhop to accomplish the task increases 
exponentially.

Now, did you envision this from the simple descriptions and visualizations? 
This is supposed to be the "infinity hotel of endless capacity", yet the 
guests really have to all wait at the check-in and in the parking lot 
queues for the rooms to actually become vacant. OBVIOUSLY, this ISN'T what 
it seems... the devil is in the details, and this is proven by actually 
"programming" a "finite hotel" and seeing what actually happens before 
making grandiose claims about what would happen in an impossible scenario.

If this were the infinity hotel, the guests would have to all wait forever 
in infinite size queues out in the parking lot, and the bellhop would have 
to perform and INFINITE number of steps just to get the first guest in, let 
alone an infinite number of busloads. What they're not telling you is that 
the first step could never occur because it requires an infinite number of 
sequential steps to be completed before proceeding to the next room... this 
scenario is IMPOSSIBLE and thus this is all total bull shit!!

OK, OK, then why doesn't the infinity hotel just use my simple backwards 
shuffling method? Why didn't they explain this stupid paradox that way? 
Once again, smoke and mirrors... if they showed you this very simple 
method, they would have needed to start at the last room in the hotel 
first, and work backwards from there... hmmm, so the first thing is to find 
infinity, which is impossible, so instead, they act as though they can 
start at room number 1 and don't have to even mention infinity... and 
instead, they try slipping it in by not addressing the actual physical 
steps it takes to accomplish the task in the forward method shown.

marty﻿
